Award.AwardTitle: Augmented Surface Acoustic Wave Devices for Microbial Cell Separation Based on Physiological Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to design, fabricate, and test flow-through microfluidic devices that will enable the selection and separation of biological cells based on their physiological properties using augmented surface acoustic wave technology. The approach will be to utilize surface acoustic wave energy as an initial separation and alignment tool and then enhance separation and selectivity through secondary and tertiary separation technologies downstream. Transverse waves as well as electrophoresis and chemical gradients will be utilized to enhance selectivity and separation of cells. The separation technologies will initially be studied using manufactured particles with different surface-chemical and physical properties as models for biological cells. These initial studies will feed data for modeling and iterating the design of microfluidic channels and surface acoustic wave devices for subsequent work with living biological cells . Studies with cells will proceed with pure cultures of cells and continue with co-cultures of cells in mixed microbial communities.

Separation of biological cells from complex mixtures is important for emergent biotechnology, human health research and national security. Currently, techniques for the selection and isolation of microbes requires ad hoc knowledge about proteins on the cells or rely on random isolation and the hopes that the desired cell has become entrapped in a micro-well or isolated by serial dilution. If successful, this body of research can transform the paradigm for separation of biological cells into one in which future researchers may sort cells based on the physiology of the desired cell rather than luck. This work will result in an understandings about how cell physiology is related to motion in surface acoustic wave energy, about the impact of water quality parameters on cellular motion in surface acoustic wave energy, and which physiological properties of biological cells are best exploited for specific separation of individuals from the mixed communities of cells. This body of work enhances the education and training pipeline that prepares the future leaders in engineering and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High-throughput, continuous separation of particles or cells by physiological properties is important in a variety of fields including medical diagnostics and treatment, and drinking water testing. This project focused on the development of acoustic-microfluidic particle and cell separation techniques.  We began this development using surface acoustic waves (SAWs) on the piezoelectric s substrate, lithium niobate. Using contact lithography, we fabricated interdigitated transducers (IDTs) on lithium niobate wafers, to excite surface acoustic waves that travel across the substrate and couple into molded, bonded, polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) microfluidic channels, creating a standing acoustic field in water in the channel.

In a standing acoustic field, cells and microparticles experience an acoustic force towards acoustic nodes in the acoustic field. The acoustic force is proportional to the particles’ volume, and related to its density, compressibility and shape. The cells and microparticles also experience a drag force from the fluid, which is proportional to the particles’ radius. By manipulating the interplay between the drag and acoustic forces, our group can create devices that separate cells or microparticles by any of the physical parameters that change these forces.

After extensive experimental and simulation studies of surface acoustic wave, continuous separation devices, we concluded that we could separate particles by size, particularly in the SAW device configuration with microfluidic flow running at a tilted angle with respect to acoustic node lines, but the PDMS channel material was introducing very significant acoustic damping, the devices required time and labor intensive contact lithography for fabrication, the device throughput was fundamentally limited by the direction SAWs must couple into a microfluidic channel, and the amount of piezoelectric material required for the device drives up device cost. Consequently, we transitioned to the development of an inexpensive, high-throughput, acoustic-microfluidic microparticle or cell separation alternative.

To address the high acoustic damping, and fabrication limitations of PDMS, we use CNC micro-machined Plexiglas (PMMA, poly(methyl methacrylate))as our microfluidic channel material. Using modern CNC micro-machining technology, Plexiglas microchannels can be rapidly fabricated, and result in a low cost, mechanically robust device. To address the throughput limitations, and amount of required piezoelectric material of SAW devices, we transitioned to the use of bulk acoustic waves excited by lead zirconate (PZT) transducers to create our standing acoustic wave field in a Plexiglas prism containing a microchannel.

These transitions led to the development of the PMMA prism device, for which we have applied for a patent. The PMMA prism device is a prism of PMMA containing PZT transducers that excite and acoustic field with standing acoustic node lines at a tilted angle with respect to fluid flow in a microfluidic channel. This device has been used to demonstrate the continuous separation of 2 and 15 micron polystyrene particles, and the alignment and separation of cells from blood.

The project resulted in numerous publications and presentations at international conferences.  A patent application for the PMMA prism device, as an inexpensive, easily to fabricate, particle or cell separation device is under review. In addition to the intellectual merit of the work completed in this project, it also supported a researcher through MS and PhD studies, and a year of Postdoctoral research, resulting in a dissertation on the topic.
